newsitem.title: UK: Dominion Resources asks to meet East Midlands.
newsitem.headline: Dominion Resources asks to meet East Midlands.

text.p: Advisers of U.S. energy group Dominion Resources Inc on Monday telephoned their potential bid target, British electricity supplier East Midlands Electricity, to ask for a first meeting, a spokesman said.

But he told Reuters that East Midlands, which has a current market capitalisation of around 1.196 billion stg, had not yet responded to the invitation for talks about a possible offer, that was first muted last week.
"We are not sure when that (meeting) will be," he added, noting that the telephone conversation had shed no light on the exact price the U.S. company was considering.
The spokesman said he believed the two companies would meet "as soon as possible".
The Virginia-based utility said on Thursday that it was considering a bid "at a price not much in excess of 608 pence per share" -- a level that was scorned by East Midlands.
A 608p per share bid would value East Midlands at about 1.2 billion stg.

East Midlands said on Monday that it had nothing to add to its statement last Thursday, in which it said it would reject an offer at such a level because it would undervalue the Nottingham-based electricity company's prospects.
The spokesman for Dominion Resources noted that the U.S. group was well aware of the uncertainties, both regulatory and political, that surrounded the purchase of a UK power group.

The popular opposition Labour Party has threatened to impose a windfall tax on the profits of the 12 cash-rich regional electricity companies and other utilities if it comes to power in the next general election, due by May 1997.
But the U.S. group may feel its bid will win approval from regulators as Britain has so far cleared three U.S. bids for regional electricity companies (RECs).
If Dominion Resources decides to make a bid, it would be the fifth U.S. bid for a REC.
CE Electric, jointly owned by CalEnergy Co and Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc, launched a hostile 650 million stg for REC Northern Electric on October 28.
East Midlands, the first of its peers to start buying back its shares in a move to return cash to shareholders, saw its stock close at 603 pence, up 9.5 pence on the day.
